awd_abstract_narration:
This award is made as part of the FY 2022 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist.

The title of the project for this fellowship to Patrick Lopatto is "Topics in Random Matrix Theory: Large Deviations and Extremal Statistics." The host institution for the fellowship is Brown University, and the sponsoring scientist is Kavita Ramanan.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on establishing new theoretical results in a branch of probability theory known as random matrix theory. The research emphasized phenomena that are in some way extremal, including questions about the largest and smallest values of certain random matrix observables, large deviations from their typical behavior, and heavy-tailed randomness (where outlying data points are particularly influential). Altogether, the PI produced nine research articles with various coauthors. Highlights of the PI's research program include rigorously establishing the existence of an Anderson transition in a heavy-tailed matrix model, which was predicted by the physics community in the early 90s, and significant progress towards the Fyodorov-Hiary-Keating conjecture for Wigner random matrices. Another achievement was the proof of a quenched large deviation principle for projections (of growing dimension) of high-dimensional measures; previous results in this regime dealt only with the technically simpler, and less informative, annealed case. The PI also gave several seminar talks on the research supported by this project in order to disseminate it. All research articles produced by this project are available to the public via the arXiv preprint repository.   Additionally, the PI also began a fruitful interdisciplinary collaboration in statistics with a political scientist and economist. Two of the research articles from this project were from this collaboration. These articles developed methods for the analysis of randomized controlled trials with good small-sample properties and minimal assumptions on the data. One of these articles was recognized with an invited presentation at the annual INFORMS operations research conference.   The PI also engaged in significant mentorship work: one article was coauthored with a high school student, one was coauthored with an undergraduate, and four had graduate student coauthors.
